title: 103_hr4477
content: The "Boating Improvement Act of 1994" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions for boating safety grants. The "Boating Improvement Act of 1994" authorizes transfers of specific amounts for State Boating Safety Programs, with varying allocations for fiscal years 1995 to 1999. An amount is designated for grants under the Clean Vessel Act of 1992. The "Boating Improvement Act of 1994" authorizes transfers of specific amounts for State Boating Safety Programs for fiscal years 1995 to 1999. Amounts are designated for grants under the Clean Vessel Act of 1992. The Secretary of the Interior has access to $10,000,000 for grants under the Boating Improvement Act of 1994 and the Clean Vessel Act of 1992 for fiscal years 1998 and 1999. Any unobligated funds will be transferred to the Secretary of Transportation for State recreational boating safety programs. Starting from fiscal year 1996, the transferred amount will be reduced. The Secretary of Transportation's funding for boating safety programs will be reduced by the lesser of the appropriated amount or $35,000,000 for fiscal years, with a lower limit of $30,000,000 for 1996. The reduction will be distributed among states by the Secretary of the Interior. In fiscal year 1996, the amount distributed under the Act of August 9, 1950 for State recreational boating safety programs cannot exceed $50,000,000. Additionally, the Secretary of Transportation will expend funds for these programs based on the amount appropriated from the Boat Safety Account for that fiscal year. The Secretary of Transportation will expend funds for State recreational boating safety programs based on the amount appropriated from the Boat Safety Account, not exceeding $35,000,000 each fiscal year. SEC. 3. BOATING ACCESS. The Congress finds that nontrailerable recreational motorboats contribute a significant portion of gasoline taxes to the Aquatic Resources Trust Fund. They believe more funds should be allocated to facilities benefiting nontrailerable vessels. The purpose of this section is to provide funds to states for developing public facilities for transient nontrailerable vessels. Within 18 months of enactment, states can submit a survey to the Secretary of the Interior identifying public facilities for nontrailerable vessels and areas of operation. Within 6 months of the survey, states can develop a plan for construction and renovation of these facilities. The Secretary of the Interior may provide matching grants for this purpose. The Secretary of the Interior may provide matching grants to states for constructing or renovating public facilities for transient nontrailerable vessels, prioritizing projects submitted by states in accordance with a plan. The Secretary of the Interior prioritizes projects in states for grants to construct or renovate public facilities for nontrailerable vessels, focusing on projects likely to serve the most vessels. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines terms such as "Act of August 9, 1950," "nontrailerable vessel," "public facilities for transient nontrailerable vessels," and "recreational vessel." The Act defines terms related to nontrailerable vessels and recreational vessels, as well as the various States and territories included in the definition of "State."
